question.text: An earthquake generates both transverse <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mfenced><mi mathvariant="normal">S</mi></mfenced></math> and longitudinal <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mfenced><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi></mfenced></math> sound waves in the earth. The speed of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal">S</mi></math> waves is about <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>6</mn><mo> </mo><mi>km</mi><mo> </mo><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msup></math> and that of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi></math> waves is about <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>9</mn><mo> </mo><mi>km</mi><mo> </mo><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msup></math>. A seismograph records <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi></math> and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal">S</mi></math> waves from an earthquake. The first <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi></math> wave arrives <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>5</mn></math> minute before the first <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal">S</mi></math> wave. The epicenter of the earthquake is located at a distance of about -

solution.text:
Let is= speed of transverse wave

and ip= speed of longitudinal wave

dis-dip=t

d6-d9=5(60)

d = 5400 km
